extractions.description: The research paper presents a framework to enhance the robustness of deep learning models for computer vision by incorporating dense intrinsic constraints at inference time rather than at training time. Utilizing equivariance to achieve this, the method significantly improves adversarial robustness across multiple datasets and tasks.

type.justification: The paper includes empirical experiments to demonstrate the performance improvements on multiple datasets and tasks.
type.quote: Our empirical experiments show that restoring feature equivariance at inference time defends against worst-case adversarial perturbations.

name.justification: The study focuses on enhancing the robustness of deep networks for computer vision tasks through equivariance.
name.quote: Deep networks for computer vision are not reliable when they encounter adversarial examples.

name.justification: The core contribution is improving the adversarial robustness of computer vision models through the novel application of equivariance.
name.quote: Our empirical experiments show that restoring feature equivariance at inference time defends against worst-case adversarial perturbations.

name.justification: The paper mentions using a pretrained DeepLabV3 model which is commonly based on ResNet50 for semantic segmentation tasks.
name.quote: We use the pretrained DeepLabV3 (Chen et al., 2018; 2017) model.

name.justification: The paper explicitly mentions using the DRN-22-d model for segmentation tasks in Cityscapes.
name.quote: We adversarially train a segmentation model and evaluate it in Table 1, which is measured with mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) for semantic segmentation.

name.justification: The paper mentions using Mask R-CNN for the instance segmentation task in MS-COCO dataset.
name.quote: We use pretrained DeeplabV3 and MaskRCNN for semantic segmentation and instance segmentation, respectively.

name.justification: The paper reports improved adversarial robustness on the ImageNet dataset.
name.quote: Our empirical experiments show that restoring feature equivariance at inference time defends against worst-case adversarial perturbations. The method obtains improved adversarial robustness on four datasets (ImageNet, Cityscapes, PASCAL VOC, and MS-COCO) on image recognition, semantic segmentation, and instance segmentation tasks.
